passages.text: Takeaways from CEO at Singtel Investor Day

At the Singtel Analyst Day, CEO Gopal Vittal and CEO Designate Shashwat Sharma highlighted continued focus on ARPU repair, growing the Homes, Cloud and Data centre businesses. BHARTI continues to scope for ARPU to rise from continued repair to Rs350- 400 over time. Recent entry- level plan changes are steps in the right direction but won't have a material impact on ARPU on their own. Mgmt views Homes as a significant multi- year opportunity as a combination of fiber and FWA where Airtel's business can more than double should \(100m\) households take this. The co's incremental focus areas for capital deployment are deleveraging, dividend increases, capex towards cloud and data centres and balance sheet leverage in digital lending. BHARTI remains our top Telecom OW.

- Significant head room for continued tariff repair. The recent tariff action on one low end pack is a welcome step, which can be a sensible way to create tiered plans to push ARPU up. However, it is unlikely to drive meaningful change in ARPU on its own. BHARTI sees adequate opportunity to keep taking pricing up towards Rs350-400 with further tariff actions given the stratified consumer base. Organic ARPU drivers remain smartphone upgraders, postpaid upgrades, roaming and data consumption.

- Homes remains a large opportunity. BHARTI is focussed single-mindedly on growing the FTTH business as a superior option to FWA and doesn't distinguish between the two. Cost per connected home pass has become comparable for FTTH and FWA at about \(\) 105\(. It expects the market to rise to\) 100m\$ households in the long term and expects its business to more than double. In the near term, the company aims to double the number of home passes added per month to \(3m\) from \(1.5m\)

- Continued scope in War on Waste. Mr Vittal sees adequate scope in its war on waste program, including using AI/ML for power savings, optimising costs using digital interactions for customer support, and in sales and distributions. The company was able to save \(\) 500m\(last year by focusing on its most expensive 100K network sites.

- Key incremental bets on Cloud and Data Centres. BHARTI is keen to invest in capex for its Cloud and DC businesses. In the DC business it has \(\sim 135MW\) of third party capacity led by hyperscalers and \(100MW\) of captive. Its current marketshare is \(\sim 10\%\) and it can add \(0.5GW\) of capacity over the next five years with opportunity largely in Mumbai led by hyperscalers and on-prem capacity outsourcing from banks and SOEs. Airtel runs one of the largest clouds in India with 250TB of storage. Its captive cloud use has helped hold IT costs at \(1.6\%\) of revenues vs MSD for global peers.

- Capital Allocation. Focus on deploying rising cash generation is across (a) continued deleverage, (b) step up dividends, (c) invest in adjacencies like Cloud and Data centres, (d) potentially use balance sheet for digital lending, and (e) taking up stakes in Indus Towers and Airtel Africa at the right price.
BRTI.NS, BHARTI IN Price (26 Aug 25):Rs1,904.70 Price Target (Jun- 26):Rs2,190.00

Key Metrics (FYE Mar)

Our OW thesis is driven by: (1) 17% tariff hikes across the portfolio, as Bharti saw success in intervention in CY23, with limited churn and a narrowing of the gap between postpaid and prepaid to 1.6x in CY24 from 3x in CY21; (2) a 15% tariff hike in Nov-25 and Nov-26, as we expect the market to stay in tariff repair into CY26/27-the tariff repair cycle was a two-year cycle in the past that was disrupted by 5G rollouts and elections, and now we expect the two-year cadence to return; and (3) a meaningful increase in dividends over FY26E/27E from improving FCF and de-leverage.

Our Jun-26 PT of Rs2,190 is based on our SOTP valuation. We value the India wireless business at 12.5x EV/EBITDA (+2SD of its five-year average) and Homes at 12.5x, Airtel businesses at 12x, while we assign a lower 10x to the Digital TV business.We incorporate the value of Airtel Africa at CMP and Indus Towers based on J.P. Morgan's fair value.
JP Morgan GBH-EM Global Div0.340.27HSI Volatility Index-0.14-0.19JPM EM Currency(EMCI) Fixing0.290.19Quant Styles:Size0.130.14LowVol0.220.12Quality0.140.11

- Digital lending. BHARTI has seen success in digital lending that is now a Rs50bn disbursement on 12m duration loans with Rs100K ATS using the balance sheet of partners such as Bajaj Finance. Its proprietary credit model has led to high collection efficiencies and a track record over the past two years. The company is evaluating whether it wants to get an NBFC license and lend using its own balance sheet.
Bharti Airtel Limited (Overweight; Price Target: Rs2,190.00)

Our Ow thesis is driven by: (1) \(17\%\) tariff hikes across the portfolio, as Bharti saw success in intervention in CY23, with limited churn and a narrowing of the gap between postpaid and prepaid to 1.6x in CY24 from 3x in CY21; (2) a \(15\%\) tariff hike in Nov- 25 and Nov- 26, as we expect the market to stay in tariff repair into CY26/27 - the tariff repair cycle was a two- year cycle in the past that was disrupted by 5G rollouts and elections, and now we expect the two- year cadence to return; and (3) a meaningful increase in dividends over FY26E/27E from improving FCF and de- leverage.

Our Jun- 26 PT of Rs2,190 is based on our SOTP valuation. We value the India wireless business at 12.5x EV/EBITDA (+2SD of its five- year average) and Homes at 12.5x, Airtel businesses at 12x, while we assign a lower 10x to the Digital TV business. We incorporate the value of Airtel Africa at CMP and Indus Towers based on J.P. Morgan's fair value.

The chart(s) show J.P. Morgan's continuing coverage of the stocks; the current analysts may or may not have covered it over the entire period. J.P. Morgan ratings or designations: OW = Overweight, N= Neutral, UW = Underweight, NR = Not Rated

J.P. Morgan uses the following rating system: Overweight (over the duration of the price target indicated in this report, we expect this stock will outperform the average total return of the stocks in the Research Analyst's, or the Research Analyst's team's, coverage universe); Neutral (over the duration of the price target indicated in this report, we expect this stock will perform in line with the average total return of the stocks in the Research Analyst's, or the Research Analyst's team's, coverage universe); and Underweight (over the duration of the price target indicated in this report, we expect this stock will underperform the average total return of the stocks in the Research Analyst's, or the Research Analyst's team's, coverage universe. NR is Not Rated. In this case, J.P. Morgan has removed the rating and, if applicable, the price target, for this stock because of either a lack of a sufficient fundamental basis or for legal, regulatory or policy reasons. The previous rating and, if applicable, the price target, no longer should be relied upon. An NR designation is not a recommendation or a rating. In Americas equity research, some stocks under coverage have a rating but no price target; in these cases, we expect the stock will outperform/perform in line/underperform the average total return of the stocks in the Research Analyst's, or the Research Analyst's team's, coverage universe over the next six to 12 months. In our Asia (ex-Australia and ex-India) and U.K. small- and mid-cap Equity Research, each stock's expected total return is compared to the expected total return of a benchmark country market index, not to those Research Analysts' coverage universe. If it does not appear in the Important Disclosures section of this report, the certifying Research Analyst's coverage universe can be found on J.P. Morgan's Research website, https://www.jpmorganmarkets.com.
